newsitem.title: CANADA: Scotiabank economists urge Canada budget surpluses.
newsitem.headline: Scotiabank economists urge Canada budget surpluses.

text.p: Canada should attempt to run annual budget surpluses of C$10 billion once the federal budget has been balanced, Bank of Nova Scotia economists said in a report released late Monday.
The report said the surpluses are needed to cushion government finances against future economic setbacks.

Prime Minister Jean Chretien has said he will balance the country's books within two years. After that, the Liberal party has said it will spend half of any surplus on social programs and the other half on tax relief and debt reduction.

"The problem with this 'spend now' approach is that it leaves no cushion for unexpected economic or financial setbacks," Warren Jestin, Scotiabank's chief economist, said in a statement. "The only way to reduce the vulnerability of federal finances to unfavourable economic circumstances is to permanently lower debt-service costs by paying down debt."

Targeting a balanced budget and relying on an unprecedented stretch of solid growth and low interest rates to reduce the debt burden would be a high-risk strategy for reducing government debt, the report said.
Canada has one of the highest debt-to-GDP ratios among the Group of Seven nations.
